channel.title: Smattering on Selenium
channel.description: Recent content in Smattering on Selenium

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #157
item.description: Trying to find every excuse not to cut the grass ‚Ä¶ including apparently closing some browser tabs. Interoperability ‚Äì Standardized Test Information Interchange has me so full of ‚Äòmeh‚Äô as to be hilarious. Commercially driven standards rarely are and/or I am just too much of an open source person to accept this model for standards development Licensing in a Post Copyright World ‚Äì important How to Make Async Requests in PHP is php specific in its solution, but has some interesting bits about socket establishment that applies to other ones as well Adding Comments to JSON feels like a hack.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #156
item.description: Brain fried from PyCon Canada 2013 and ‚Äòsome‚Äô browser tab is misbehaving which means its time to start closing some of these. Patchwork seems like an awesome idea, but at the same time, I‚Äôve had to work in heavily monkey-patched RoR apps before‚Ä¶ Evolving syntax is PHP specific in its examples, but the ideas transfer Roslyn + Selenium: Scripty C# Powering Browser Automation ‚Äì some C# voodoo? It‚Äôs like 10000 knives when all you need is a Spoon ‚Äì or specifically, this particular spoon which is yet-another-android-automation-tool.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #155
item.description: A ‚Äòshould be scripting, but brain stuck in neutral so closing some tabs‚Äô edition of the Smattering. The slippery slope isn‚Äôt automation related, but if your employer does these things I‚Äôd suggest logging a bug and then finding an ethical job Why Package Signing is not the Holy Grail ‚Äì crypto / security is hard. Also, I have a signed package for you to install‚Ä¶ PHP and Async requests with file based sessions could be a way to speed up a PHP site.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #154
item.description: Apparently today‚Äôs ‚Äòwait for an email‚Äô task is to whittle down the smattering queue some more. I won‚Äôt even pretend that FOAAS has to do with automation, but makes me laugh. Also, depending on how crappy your place of work is, it might not be SFW PHP RFC: Importing namespaced functions is interesting if you are writing your scripts in a Functional manner. In PHP. In a future where it gets accepted and implemented.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #153
item.description: A Sunday Smattering? Sure! Solution to the Selenium with Firefox 22 Issues and How to Report Issues ‚Äì Open Source is hard. Supporting Open Source‚Äôs infrastructure is harder ‚Äî by a large margin frequests ‚Äì asyncronous HTTP Requests; not sure where I would use this, but‚Ä¶ why I don‚Äôt touch crypo ‚Äì again, don‚Äôt. touch. crypto Five reasons why you should quote attribute values in HTML5 ‚Äì for the record, you should do this in HTML 4 as well.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #152
item.description: 40-ish minutes until midnight eastern so that counts as two days in a row, right? Right? Improving jenkins execution times by common sense ‚Äî common sense. sadly lacking most days. How to make test automation more effective? is useful up until the pitch at the end. So read until you get to that. Data Structures for PHP Devs: Trees ‚Äì non-trivial data structures are non-trivial Writing clean WebDriver test suites for ‚Äúduplicate‚Äù functionality by parameterizing on page objects ‚Äì I especially like the usage of ‚Äòmight‚Äô at the top dalek-internal-webdriver ‚Äì what‚Äôs a day without a JS webdriver implementation?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #151
item.description: Almost a month after the last one. Though it did nice to have it at 150 when people go to the blog ‚Ä¶ but a greater number is nicer. So I was trying to find Requests for PHP whilst talking to the grumpy programmer and he pointed me out to Guzzle which looks equally cool Can you optimize list(genexp) is one of those geeky language internals things that could be handy to have in your back pocket Slightly Snarky GWT Debug ID FAQ ‚Äì c‚Äômon, when have you seen a more blatantly ‚Äòput this in the smattering‚Äô title than this?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #150
item.description: Yup, this smattering has very little to do with Selenium, but‚Ä¶ 150! Referencing DOM from JS: there must be a DRYer, safer way is a nice ‚Äòhere is where I started, and here is how I ended up where I am‚Äô post which can be stolen into other languages / frameworks other than in Backbone Hash lookup in Ruby, why is it so fast? is not something I was wondering, but now I know why.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #149
item.description: Too. Many. Tabs. Internationalization and Localization Testing ‚Äî yup, I agree. 5 HTML5 Features you need to know ‚Äì ‚Äòdownload attribute‚Äô and ‚Äòdatalist element‚Äô might be a pain for us automators. Or at least cause a couple hours annoyance until we figure out the pattern. Death to sleeps! Raise of Conditions! ‚Äì expected conditions is likely the next thing to get more marketing this year line_profiler and kernprof ‚Äì profiling is black magic voodoo Naught ‚Äì ‚ÄòNaught is a toolkit for building Null Objects in Ruby.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #148
item.description: Gotta start this up again‚Ä¶ The Evil Tester Guide To HTTP Proxies appears to be more for using proxies for manual testing, but you should be running your automation through one as well so it helps to understand the magic that takes place. New BrowserMob Proxy release. Bindings should all be updated for the newly exposed methods in a couple days. 5 Things You Should Stop Doing With jQuery ‚Äì Not sure whats better, the content, or the Saved By The Bell theme testtools is the latest hotness in the world of Python runners?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #147
item.description: My. Get. Productive. I know! I‚Äôll push out a smattering. Oh. ‚Ä¶ Python for Ruby Programmers is a pretty good deck, with the requisite snark at the end that you can safely ignore. Me @ Selenium Camp 2013 is Ivan‚Äôs mini-experience-report from SeCamp and has his slides on GhostDriver Using pip in production? pip install : Lightspeed and Bulletproof is a useful trick which I know I‚Äôve done variants of with java and ruby in the past SeConf speakers are up ‚Äî and the list looks really good Interfaces or Abstract Classes?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #146
item.description: Happy ‚Äòproductivity destructive week‚Äô ‚Äî otherwise known as March break. How to Accept Self-Signed SSL Certificates in Selenium 2 ‚Äî or you could use ‚Äòreal‚Äô certificates that are trusted by the browser by default. If you are using self-signed certificates to ‚Äòsave money‚Äô and you spend 3 hours making it work, you are not saving money anymore JockeyJS seems like it could be useful Dear every-js-widget-library-author, You can‚Äôt create a button If you are using PHP, then The Grumpy Programmer‚Äôs PHPUnit Cookbook should be added to your reading pile.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #145
item.description: Alice Finch builds massive LEGO Hogwarts from 400,000 bricks starts out at awesome and goes somewhere further down the scale when you get to the photo that shows scale. Models of Automation ‚Äî really, who reading this hasn‚Äôt had the conversation described in there in one of its variants Stop Moving So I Can Click You Dammit! ‚Äì illustrates the only acceptable place for Thread.sleep() Using Realistic Data in Unit Testing and AngelaSmith: Creating Test Data is a two-for for the C# crowd ‚Äî though the ideas resonate with everyone else How to handle common components with Page Object Model?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #144
item.description: Real Canadians watch curling instead of hockey. jsPerf is a performance oriented sandbox The Myth Of Convention Over Configuration ‚Äì hint: its curation over configuration. And since this is how frameworks work‚Ä¶ sublimetext_indentxml is a sublime text plugin to indent xml ‚Äî yes, originality counts with plugin naming Introducing Boxen ‚Äì Boxen feels a lot like Vagrant, but for Macs? Maybe? Checking for Technical Requirements in a Sign-up Process ‚Äî woah, this would be a pain to automate office_docs looks like it might help parse and inspect ms office docs your app generates.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #143
item.description: If you had anything interesting last week I should have seen, you‚Äôll have to resend it to me or @seleniumhq ‚Äî things were a bit crashy. So ‚Ä¶ Opera switching to WebKit. That doesn‚Äôt mean you can write off automation with Opera though. Tragedy of the WebKit Commons Introducing ChemistryKit ‚Äî a Ruby version of Saunter is another self-serving link. Automated local accessibility testing using WAVE and WebDriver is a post I had been waiting awhile for How Did the Duck Hunt Gun Work?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #142
item.description: Its a Wiggle your brain kind of morning‚Ä¶ Automated Web Testing Is Hard is the launch announcement of ChemistryKit Watir-WebDriver with GhostDriver on OSX: headless browser testing ‚Äî the WebDriver version of this would be very, very similar to this. jQuery 1.9.1 Released isn‚Äôt interesting from a new jQuery perspective, but the migrate plugin is. Likely old news, but was new to me‚Ä¶ GRASP (object-oriented design) ‚Äòis really a mental toolset‚Äô How Not to Design Pairwise Software Tests is even more useful when paired (pun intended) with‚Ä¶ Using Data Driving Wisely The Importance of the DOM has a lot of stuff that my not-in-gear brain is capable of processing, but‚Ä¶ Postel‚Äôs Principle is a Bad Idea.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #141
item.description: Its -12 Celsius plus windchill out. Why the heck is the office air conditioning on. Feel like I need a Mr. Rogers cardigan or something. Caret Navigation in Web Applications starts slow and then hurts your brain while reminding you that this automation thing isn‚Äôt easy. I don‚Äôt know NUnit or TeamCity so don‚Äôt know if Using TeamCity and NUnit to Start WebServer, Run Selenium Tests and Stop WebServer is useful or just a rehash of common knowledge.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #140
item.description: Buckets! I suspect that scanner-backed-by-selenium belongs in the ‚Äòwith great power comes great responsibility‚Äô bucket ios-driver is in the ‚Äòwouldn‚Äôt it be nice if Apple provided this‚Äô bucket Selenium WebDriver utility for determining when page has finished rendering is in the ‚ÄòADF specific‚Äô bucket‚Äô I suspect JSErrorCollector is in the ‚Äòalready indirectly linked to‚Äô bucket. If not then its in the ‚ÄòFF only‚Äô bucket Using a business readable language for browser automation is in the ‚Äòbdd/atdd hype‚Äô bucket.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #139
item.description: Posting from the past into the future. Or something‚Ä¶ (its a scheduled post). webdriverjs-with-jasmine appears appropriately named since it claims to be A standalone (includes standalone Selenium server (30Mo) + includes Jasmine) working example of a test with WebDriverJS and Jasmine. Similar to the above, but with Drupal and Behat ‚Äì Classic How I[he] send notifications to the build breakers. using twillio On Code Review comes from the Food For Thought department Orc is a model driven orchestration tool for the deployment of application clusters.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #138
item.description: <insert snark here> Debugging For Testers ‚Äî they don‚Äôt teach this in testing school. Actually, there is a testing school‚Ä¶ A million times this!! That‚Äôs not BDD, that‚Äôs just Cucumber Faster Websites: Crash Course on Web Performance ‚Äî all three hours of video Continuous Integration of iOS Projects using Jenkins, CocoaPods, and Kiwi Clearing IE‚Äôs Caches ‚Äì Not as simple as it appears is another one of those things that gives Jim headaches.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #137
item.description: Whoops, missed a couple days‚Ä¶ ah well. MOAR ELEMENTS!!! the element Dependency injection != Inversion of Control is useful reading. And the Waffle example is pretty funny. Not sure yet how I feel about this feature in the page-object gem. Waiting for an application to be fully loaded has some more examples of using a ‚Äòproper‚Äô [not implicit] waiting strategy. Most of us are not using Se for HVAT, but knowing the terminology, etc.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #136
item.description: Someone go back to my past self and punch him for thinking that starting to get in shape was a good idea. OMGCANTMOVE. .NET Goes Immutable seems interesting. But I don‚Äôt really speak C# so it could very well be boring and uninteresting. Shadow DOM 101 is another part of HTML5 that makes me think this web automation stuff has a very limited life span. Between this and Canvas‚Ä¶ ugh. Using WebDriver to automatically check for JavaScript errors on every page is something I have been considering adding to my frameworks‚Ä¶ Have I mentioned how much Canvas worries me?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #135
item.description: Three in a row ‚Ä¶ of course, these are the easy three. Build, test and deploy Firefox OS apps for $0 (or any other currency that I don‚Äôt know how to emit) Ruby on Rails ‚Ä¶ in Bash. Because they can. Bash on Balls All you need to know about CSS Transitions except how the hell we are going to synchronize on them. Well, kinda does, but this is going to hurt.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #134
item.description: Hrm. Office is closed until Monday, but everyone is in. Very confusing‚Ä¶ One reason I have heard people say they don‚Äôt use cloud instances is they are afraid they will just sit around idle when not needed. Behind the clouds: how RelEng do Firefox builds on AWS has some useful scripts to find and teardown machines. Page Weight Matters is a fun little insight into how/why YouTube shed some of its heft.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #133
item.description: Since today is the start of ‚Äòfind a new contract‚Äô I guess I don‚Äôt have an excuse to miss these for the next week or so. (Oh, and Happy New Year, etc.) This is snark, but just makes me laugh given the hype machine around ATDD/BDD; AS an angry userI WANT TO punch the developer in the faceSO THAT I CAN punch the developer in the face. ‚Äî Kristopher Johnson (@OldManKris) December 4, 2012

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #132
item.description: 2.27.0 is now out which means you can close the browser tab that points to the old Firefox installers. Not Providing an HTML Page? Think of the Kittens! is important to remember. We want to fix your bugs. Help us help you! The HTML5 download attribute is another bit I am not looking forward to have to automate Refactoring to Improve Testability ‚Äì what can I say? I like experiential posts Oh how it pains me to suggest that SikuliWebDriver looks mighty cool Page Visibility API Support in Opera 12.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #131
item.description: Not sure how widely broadcast this has been (cus, you know, we‚Äôre good at communicating and stuff), but if you are using 2.26.0 and Firefox 17 you will get a nasty bug. 2.27.0 is in the works to address this (and a couple other things‚Ä¶) so if you need FF right now, keep your install at the latest 16 release. This is pretty decent. Except the usual ‚ÄúFeh! We don‚Äôt need humans to test!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #130
item.description: Can‚Äôt get enough Se bloggage? Have a look at Overview of Selenium Blogs ‚Äî though I must say there has to be something wrong with the Alexa algorithm if I am that far down the list. And behind both David and Alister. üôÇ Must Have Git Aliases: Advanced Examples reminds me of someone I used to work with who likely couldn‚Äôt function on a clean unix system, but with all his aliases was mind blowing to watch Writing a Selenium Test Framework for a Django Site (Part 3) has the usual myths and FUD around XPath and embeds locators in the script method but is the first thing I‚Äôve seen that uses the Color class in Python so I‚Äôll overlook those things.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #129
item.description: A hardy welcome back to work to our American friends who spent Thursday being thankful for what they had, then getting into fist fights at stores for things they thought they didn‚Äôt need the next day. You know what would be grand? If various widget makers would provide automation hooks for their stuff so we, as automators, don‚Äôt have to write them ourselves. Like for High Charts (in Java) Why you should never use a boolean field (use an Enum instead) is food for thought when designing your page objects Do you work for Google?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #128
item.description: ‚Ä¶as I avoid writing code that deals with dynamically constructed tables. Without any sort of unique locator. Of course. I would contend that the ‚Äòright‚Äô solution to this problem is to use a CI container and have it email you, but if you are using Java and not using CI, then Automatically Email the Reports After Selenium Test Execution could be valuable. I feel like I have already linked to Webdriver StaleElementReferenceException but the archive search is, erm, not great, so here it is again.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #127
item.description: Within an hour I had some more things to add to the last Smattering. Oh well, I‚Äôll just save them up‚Ä¶ Har-assert looks like something useful to include in your project if you are using Java. And the browsermob-proxy (which of course, you all are) Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.0 seems like something more people should care about. Right. Here is another cool part of the nebulous, meaningless thing called HTML5.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #126
item.description: I‚Äôve been threatening that I was going to do this for awhile‚Ä¶ What it feels like when you are running a long running batch of scripts‚Ä¶ Remember kids, your script cannot adapt to the unexpected‚Ä¶ But on occasion they can do something that‚Ä¶ Oh! Here‚Äôs a useful metric of productivity! And just when you thought you were doing something without anyone paying attention‚Ä¶ Unfortunately what a lot of automation is like‚Ä¶

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #125
item.description: Right‚Ä¶ Scripting batch 1: waiting for an email Scripting batch 2: waiting for an email Scripting batch 3: waiting for an email Scripting batch 4: waiting for an email Perhaps I‚Äôll do something else right now‚Ä¶ Alright kids, its not the Olympics, but Curvy would be a fun app for someone to automate. Wow that was fast. √òredev has started to publish the videos from this year‚Äôs conference. Lots of good things in there.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #124
item.description: Too. Many. Links. Not. Enough. Posts. The important word is strive in 100% Automation Pass Rates. PHP Error could be interesting to turn on in your automation environment. Well, if it is a PHP app at any rate‚Ä¶ Testing mobile? Tap Into Mobile Application Testing by Jonathan Kohl Behavioural testing in .Net with SpecFlow and Selenium ‚Äì Part 1, Part 2 cocoa-rest-client could be a useful tool for the toolbox if you are on mac and are testing rest apps.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #123
item.description: If you are not using something like Chef or Puppet to keep your grid nodes behaving then you are absolutely doing it wrong. Here are all the PuppetConf 2012 Videos to help you get started. See also this Apple‚Äôs Lightning port dynamically assigns pins to allow for reversible use is just too geeky not to include. Hurray for hardware lock-in? Websockets 101 ‚Äî again, if your app uses a technology, you better be damned clueful about it if you are going to automate it Child Elements seems to address the ‚Äòis my element where I expect it‚Äô problem though I‚Äôm still not convinced that is a problem that needed solving HTML for Icon Font Usage could be interesting.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #122
item.description: Let‚Äôs try the ‚Äòall video‚Äô edition this time. Solving Common Problems with Web UI Automation Hrm. That didn‚Äôt work ‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs add some slide decks. Mobile Test Automation at eBay from Dominik Dary PHPUnit Best Practices A Whirlwind Tour of Test::Class from Curtis Poe Simple Log Analysis and Trending from Mike Brittain

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #121
item.description: Its the ‚Äòall github‚Äô edition today! Dave goes a little strange on us with his diy_framework as an emoting robot. Here is the deck that went along with it. Can‚Äôt get enough of the food-based frameworks from the kids at Sauce. If you are using the PHPUnit included WebDriver bindings [and Sauce OnDemand] then Sausage could be of interest. Of course, if you are just using PHPUnit, then paraunit could of interest.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #120
item.description: Here we grow again. Telerik acquires Fiddler. What‚Äôs next?. So. When can we look for nice Se integration with Fiddler then? Third-Party Issues and the Performance Ripple Effect is interesting, and something I‚Äôve harped on consistently. Automated Web Testing with Selenium is 3.5 hours of videos on Se. That has my usual complaints; shouldn‚Äôt have Se-IDE, there is no such thing as ‚Äòbasic‚Äô and ‚Äòadvanced‚Äô, etc. But its there. The Oracle Problem and the Teaching of Software Testing is long, but important to understand when doing automation.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #119
item.description: Its that time again, 4th Annual Automation Honors Voting is now open. Vanity contests FTW! Introducing the Sauce Plugin for Selenium Grid from a product perspective is huge. And in a roundabout way proves I am not completely crazy‚Ä¶ Benchmark of Python WSGI Servers has lots of numbers, and graphs and charts. Seleno makes some bold marketing statements (‚Äòthe RIGHT way!‚Äô). Looks like a framework in C# that forces people to use Page Objects

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #118
item.description: <Insert witty/snarky commentary on something here> Apparently the TestWatchman thing I linked to is deprecated now in favour of TestWatcher (shows how much I pay attention to JUnit stuff‚Ä¶). Here is an example of TestWatchers and RuleChains. No, I don‚Äôt know what the blurb at the top says. Sure, we‚Äôve all see lorum ipsum text, but do you know what it (ish) says? now you do From the ‚ÄòMEASURE ALL THINGS!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #117
item.description: Evolutionary Project Structure talks about a particular project structure, but this is one of those fun developer opinionated things to geek out on Testers Caught Sleeping on the Job is not browser-based, but you cannot bash sleeps enough. Also has a pretty amusing photo with it PHP: The Right Way is of course one person‚Äôs understanding of the ‚Äòright way‚Äô but still not bad. Automation is Code. But are your code conventions hurting you?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #116
item.description: So do people celebrate the day after Labor day as the beginning of summer? Web Performance Power Tool: HTTP Archive (HAR) is worrisome that HARs are being billed as a power tool, but full of good stuff How do you pick responsive images breakpoints? is another one of those problems I think we‚Äôre going to have to worry about TestWatchman seems like an interesting bit of JUnit4. (At what point do we have to stop saying 3 or 4 when referring to JUnit?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #115
item.description: The big news in the twitter-verse yesterday was the announcement of Apple Sauce and Android Sauce from Sauce Labs. I of course jumped all over that bandwagon with Apple Sauce and Android Sauce .. Yummy! (And Fully Supported) * Accessing priviledged Javascript APIs from your web page in Firefox with Selenium lets to pull even more strings of the browser than you were supposed to be able to. Something I suspect Marionette will make redundant, but until then‚Ä¶

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #114
item.description: Hurray for having fillings done on both sides of my face. Don‚Äôt expect me to speak without drolling for rest of the day. I‚Äôll admit to not knowing what the difference is/was between FluentWait and WebDriverWait, but FluentWait with WebElement explains it well. With sample code! PHPUnit + Selenium + php-webdriver = hours of entertainment (Part 1) shows a nice extension to PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase. Now if only he was using my active fork of the php-webdriver bindings rather than the original project Facebook seems to have abandoned.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #113
item.description: /me is not looking forward to when the jet lag whallops him Thorough look at PHP‚Äôs pcntl_fork() is how we have to do parallel tests with phpunit until it grows it proper Catch Javascript Errors on the Page with Watir or Selenium ‚Äì This! Categorising WebDriver‚ÄìNavigation, Interrogation, Manipulation walks through the WebDriver API bit by bit. Of course, now the trick is to keep it up to date. üôÇ Screening uses Se deep in its guts to script up Montage apps Millions of web pages use the -moz-opacity:0.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #112
item.description: Eyes are gross. Thucydides has a spiffy new website How Eventbrite uses Jenkins and Selenium which I think I‚Äôve linked to before, but can‚Äôt seem to find reference to. What‚Äôs my UDID? is now the new bar for online tutorials Creating Maintainable Automated Acceptance Tests from Jez Humble Selenium Users Anonymous from Dave Haeffner Capture/Playback: The Vampire that Will Not Die has perhaps the most unfriendly url in the history of the internets, but is a nice little rant anyways.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #111
item.description: When this gets published, I‚Äôll be sitting around the Barcelona airport waiting for my connection home. Unless I screwed up the time math. üôÇ The dangers of uniformity pours cold water on something that I know I used to preach for automation environments. How to crawl a quarter billion webpages in 40 hours doesn‚Äôt have code listed (he explains why) but it explains how you could write it yourself if you wanted.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #110
item.description: Dear body; what time zone are you in? Ah well, until that battle resolves itself, here are some links. Firefox the Clear Winner for Automated Testing has a wonderfully SEO friendly title, but really is just some cool usage graphs for their system. Extrapolate beyond that at your own risk. Task Automation FTW! ‚Äî make your application installable! I did something like this a decade ago (also using python) but finding something in my own blog seems a harder challenge than it should be.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #109
item.description: Going to be on an airplane for the better part of the next day, so will likely miss some links ‚Ä¶ unless I am tagged on twitter with it. Introducing The Driver Binary Downloader Maven Plugin For Selenium solves a problem that has been solved a couple times but this seems the slickest. Normally I would suggest just using Chef/Puppet for this but it makes sense in the Maven context. I think.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #108
item.description: Apparently the links are slowing down for the summer? Ralph Bodenner talks about New Relic‚Äôs experiences at the SF Continuous Delivery meetup Xelenium: Security Testing with Selenium! is kinda an interesting use case Introducing mobile browser automation from/with Opera A minimal WebDriver based DSL is a bit of an experiment Testing Chef Cookbooks is something you didn‚Äôt think you needed to think about NASA‚Äôs github is not Se focused, but could help you build your own Mars rover WordPress Performance is a nice deck with lots of graphs and pictures Principles of Agile Test Automation outlines 4 principles and how they can often compete with each other Cucumber.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #107
item.description: Back on the train again. Wow, the highway is screwed today. The Automation Litmus Test is one that most companies face, but now it has a name Okay, who has more info on the bots mentioned in Meet the ‚Äòbots‚Äô that edit Wikipedia? Highly doubt that they are Se powered, but it is a fun mental image Custom PHPUnit Annotations is useful magic if you are building out a framework

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #106
item.description: In case you are curious, the train just went past my old neighbourhood. Marionette ‚Äì The Future of FirefoxDriver in Selenium is a project that has been hinted at here before I think, but this is its coming out party. Oh. And its the future of the Firefox driver. Now, what I need is an A-Team t-shirt‚Ä¶ FlynnID 0.2 changes its config format. I don‚Äôt play around with Grid much (at all) but I‚Äôve been told that you need this if you are going to have Android devicii attached to the grid.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #105
item.description: This was supposed to go out Friday, but the flu bug I picked up decided to move the schedule about somewhat. As Se marches towards being a W3C standard, the sort of thing in OAuth and API Providers: Come on guys. scares me more and more. Why WP_Error Sucks. Intelligent error handling is hard. Especially when you have a legacy install base to deal with. A nice little rant. Normally you see lists from people about books individuals want to see written, but Heroku has gone one step further and has released Contribute a Dev Center Article of articles they want to see written about how to use their stuff.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #104
item.description: I think everyone is on holidays right now‚Ä¶ Firefox 15 plugs the add-on leaks ‚Äî Hey look! Openness from Mozilla! I‚Äôm not kidding when I say I want to see more of these; from all browser vendors. JUnit Oath ‚Äî when geeks collide! Integration Tests With Cucumber-Jvm, Selenium and Maven is nice in that is shows the use of profiles (which is pretty much maven‚Äôs killer feature) but it uses Se-RC.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #103
item.description: Seems I had this all ready to go yesterday‚Ä¶ oh, and Happy Birthday Jim Evans ‚Äî maintainer of IE and C# driver. If also a day late. Migrating Unit Tests from Selenium to Watir Webdriver is less about migrating rather than a quick overview of Watir HttpWatch 8.4: Supports Firefox 14 and Selenium appears to be http traffic monitor ‚Äî minus a proxy sms is a quick script which will send an sms from the commandline ‚Äî using Se as the means of doing it Buster.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #102
item.description: Apparently my body isn‚Äôt quite on left coast time‚Ä¶ Butter Performance is a nice experience report on making a [big] html table behave. All sorts of headaches this would cause for automation. I‚Äôm now starting to think more about caching since some of that information is included in HAR files. So if you are automating against a Rails site, Advanced Caching in Rails: Revised could be of values Scaling lessons learned at Dropbox, part 1 is another fun experience report including a bit of hints at Dropbox‚Äôs own version of Netflix‚Äôs Chaos Monkey Finding the broken links in a webpage using Selenium is Se-RC, but the idea is sound.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #101
item.description: Really? A drought for most of the week and now I‚Äôve got a queue again in the span of 3 hours? Developing RESTful Web APIs with Python, Flask and MongoDB is toolchain dependent, but likely enough cross-tool-ism to be worth a quick click through The cool part of Jasmine Testing With Sauce Labs isn‚Äôt necessarily the Jasmine part, but the Sauce Connect Puppet part. Though Jasmine is high on my cool list.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #100
item.description: Century! Event 1028 ‚Äì Automatic Download Blocking looks like something that could be useful to have tucked away in your head somewhere I think I said I wasn‚Äôt going to link to headless gem posts, but I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve linked to one about Cucumber. Cucumber running headless Selenium with Jenkins (the easy way); fixed Errorception, and things like it, are the next wave of infrastructure to come I think now that things like BrowserMob Proxy are becoming mainstream-ish-er I‚Äôm not really sure of the difference between NPageObject.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #99
item.description: With the queue flushed we‚Äôll go back to our regular random posting schedule Etsy Code as Craft: The Other Part of Software Architecture with Coda Hale ‚Äì Code as Craft talks are generally good All the Atlassian Summit 2012 talks. I love this trend. Perception Of Performance discusses the whole ‚ÄòOMG CHOME IS HELLA FAST ON IOS!!!!!!‚Äô madness. As the last line of the article says, I present to you, the power of marketing!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #98
item.description: Happy day off Canuckistan! I‚Äôll be in California in two weeks; here is my schedule ‚Äî come by and chat Selenium Rc to Webdriver Migration ‚Äì Part2 is included mainly for the IE bit. Busted SSL certificate? Don‚Äôt work around the problem ‚Äî fix it! Can‚Äôt find an element? Synchronize properly ‚Äî don‚Äôt just bap it in the face with the magic implicit wait wand‚Ä¶ Google I/O 2012 Videos won‚Äôt give you the loot attendees got, just the content.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #97
item.description: Yes. I know. I missed a day. But 13 in a row was a good run! Free Automated Cross-Browser JavaScript Testing is a pretty standard ‚Äòhere is how you do it‚Äô article ‚Äî until you get to the IE section. It has a trick I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve seen yet. If you don‚Äôt want to use a Proxy to generate HAR files, you can use NetExport in your Firefox profile to save things locally, or sent them to a remote server as explained in Automate Page Load Performance Testing with Firebug and Selenium.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #96
item.description: Blech. Supposed to go car shopping today. Any car brands want to sponsor my wife with a car so I can do something productive? Worth a shot‚Ä¶ jbehave-selenium is a sample project that uses, unsurprisingly, jbehave and selenium. Sample projects are outstanding. Just as samples are good, so are playgrounds. It‚Äôs playtime ‚Äì Light Table Playground released And try jasmine! Announcing Joyride is another ‚Äòbrowser automation without programming as a service‚Äô site Announcing pytest-mozwebqa 1.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #95
item.description: Ok twitterverse. After 2 weeks of very few links a day you explode. Testing JSF with Arquillian and Selenium apparently will save the world. GhostDriver: almost 50% is an update on something that got a bit of momentum at SeConf2012 Building and profiling high performance systems with Iago is getting a bump by being released at/during Velocity. Not browser based, but what its being used for doesn‚Äôt need browsers. Testing geolocation with capybara + selenium + firefox is an interesting trick to address something I haven‚Äôt thought of needing yet.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #94
item.description: # sudo wget coffee > adam Selenium-RC Commands is a mindmap of all the commands in Se-RC. (Unsurprising really.) I keep meaning to do this for WebDriver. quacken is a script for grabbing OFX files from Quicken it seems What‚Äôs that? You weren‚Äôt happy with one of the six PHP WebDriver clients that were out there already? Have another one ‚Äî Nearsoft/PHP-SeleniumClient. It‚Äôd be spooky what would happen if we all got together on this.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #93
item.description: Did I say 8 days in a row yesterday? I meant 9. Good thing programming doesn‚Äôt require counting‚Ä¶ Passing ruby instance variables from Rspec to mix ins is the sort of nonsense you need to do when framework writing. Scared yet? (But it is fun‚Ä¶) Rspec, page objects and user flows is the experiment that likely led to the link above puppet-sauceconnect is a puppet module for moving Sauce‚Äôs Sauce Connect daemon onto remote nodes.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #92
item.description: What‚Äôs that? Eight days in a row? That‚Äôs right‚Ä¶ lolcommits seems almost funny enough to be a good idea A vision for Cucumber 2.0 is rather interesting Install Firefox on Amazon Linux X86_64 Compiling GTK+ is not something I have had to do. But then again, I haven‚Äôt tried. Nerrvana is yet another Selenium-As-A-Service provider. Looks like they are taking the ‚Äòupload to our servers and run as a scheduled job‚Äô approach rather than real-time.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #91
item.description: As you‚Äôll start to see by the timestamps of things towards the end, I‚Äôm running out of ‚Äònew‚Äô stuff and am pulling from the queue now. Fairly certain I‚Äôve linked to this before, but seleniumwrapper adds some syntacitcal sugar around the Python bindings. Though not sure that it makes it clearer to me. What the heck is an xrange? is today‚Äôs Python internal geekiness post Functional Automated Testing Best Practices with Selenium WebDriver is the video version of these slides (wow I dislike this html slide deck trend‚Ä¶) All the WWDC 2012 Session Videos are now up.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #90
item.description: Eventually I‚Äôll get back on the once-a-week schedule. But not today! Falsehoods Programmers believe about Time. Time is hard; let‚Äôs go shopping! Speaking of hard. Concurrency is not Parallelism (it‚Äôs better) (http://concur.rspace.googlecode.com/hg/talk/concur.html) ‚Äî also has gophers Did Netflix actually Open Source Army of Cloud Monkeys? I don‚Äôt see anything on their github account (and that is the trendy place to release stuff these days) Need I say more? I‚Äôve used this trick a couple times Python introspection ‚Äì how to check current module / line of call from within function Ah-ha!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #89
item.description: Figured I would get this out before the computer goes in for surgery. Automate Page Load Performance Testing with Firebug and Selenium is not a new topic, but a timely one for me Speed up your features with a backdoor login route is not a recent post, but something I‚Äôve had to explain to people at least once a week for the past month, so‚Ä¶ RSpec‚Äôs New Expectation Syntax explains not only the ‚Äòwhat‚Äô of the new syntax but the ‚Äòwhy‚Äô Slides & Videos from LDNSE #6 does not falsely advertise itself Python Timer Class ‚Äì Context Manager for Timing Code Blocks reminds me that I need to use Context Managers more often Overloading Python list comprehension is an interesting little experiment.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #88
item.description: Five days and fifty links later‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm working on a larger-ish rant on headless browsers, but until then there is Jasmine Headless WebKit Not 2. Not 4. But Three ways to generate test data for your ruby automated tests Downloading things is a pain, but Waiting for watir-webdriver downloads (and determining the file name) has a solution Use classes in Python? Of course you do! Under the hood of Python class definitions ‚Äî but as the warning states, If the prospect of pondering the metaclass of the metaclass of your class makes you feel nauseated, you better stop now.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #87
item.description: Avoiding punching things about software packaging by doing the 4th!!!! smattering in row. Python Decorators is an attempt at picking up a stick the right way A lawnchair is sorta like a couch except smaller and outside. And a persistence solution for HTML5 apps. If your apps persist data, checking them in the browser is. Not. Enough. Atlassian is building a performance tool off of WebDriver including Page Objects called soke I wonder if we should fail scripts that use vendor prefixes‚Ä¶How to Unprefix -Webkit-Device-Pixel-Ratio The last paragraph in Android unittests now have LOLcat is the sort of thing that more projects should do tl;dw: Speedily practical large-scale tests ‚Äî of course, browsers are going to slow things in any event, but things to think about‚Ä¶ Continuous Deployment as a Remedy for Burnout ‚Äî hadn‚Äôt thought about it this way, but yup.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #86
item.description: Look at that! 3 days in a row, and the boy isn‚Äôt even gone to school yet and I‚Äôve hit ‚Äòpublish‚Äô Most people know about this already, but SeleniumConf has its own YouTube channel ‚Äî which has all of the 2012 videos on it now. How to Dynamically Add Android Support to Selenium Server at Runtime Python Iteration is a beginner talk about, well, iterating in Python. In ways that you would expect (for) and ways that you wouldn‚Äôt (generators) Sleepy Automated Tests talks about polling loops.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #85
item.description: Two days in a row! Take that doubters! Automated Software Testing: An Example of a Working Solution is an interesting take on designing an automation system for the US DoD. It sure as heck isn‚Äôt how I would do it, but I can understand how this context might lead to this solution. And it seems like it is Eclipse based which is even worse a decision. üôÇ 5 Tips on Finding a Mobile Job in Toronto is pretty focused, but also applies to non-mobile jobs outside of Toronto.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #84
item.description: What? Its only been 3 months since the last one. Sheesh. Sorry about being a G+ article, but DOM Ready discusses briefly about how to build your page in terms of order of events. Of course, if you read the comments it is very much buyer beware, but‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve been fixating a bit on operational dashboards the last little while and Enterprise Operational Intelligence has a couple good ones Looking to use BrowserID?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #83
item.description: Well, might not be in Florida, but how about them juggernaut Blue Jays? WebDriver: capture JS errors while running tests is a JS way of capturing JS errors on a page Selenium reports ‚Äì our take is a pretty detailed report on one company‚Äôs drive for prettier report output Hmmm. How do we get a Selenium coderwall achievement? page-objects is A basic framework for running automated tests using WebDriver, TestNG & Gradle selenese-runner is a js runner of Selenese scripts including a JUnit style reporter.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #82
item.description: Someone explain to me why I‚Äôm in Toronto and not Florida? Couldn‚Äôt make it to Pycon last week? There are videos of the session! Release Histories for all Major Browsers is just interesting from a historical perspective Interacting with web pages using Selenium WebDriver for C# is pretty basic but does include the all-important security settings to make IE behave-ish page-object 0.6.2 released is not just a release announcement but has some nice examples of page objects in ruby autoenv is a magic hack for having auto-firing scripts at a directory level.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #81
item.description: Its March Break (at least here) which means its also Catch Up Week. An extra long Smattering every day! Generally I reccomend to people not to automate file uploads, but sometimes they are unavoidable. Selenium Tips: Uploading Files in Remote WebDriver explains how one might go about things in WebDriver HTTP Status Cats isn‚Äôt new, but is still funny. httpstatus.es has the same information, but organized slightly differently. Now for someone to make a mashup of the two Coypu appears to be a .

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #80
item.description: I should have learned not to boast about getting caught up with links. Automating BrowserID with Selenium is pretty awesome. (As is BrowserID.) Now if this was only installable via pip or easy_install‚Ä¶ Ruby Trick Shots ‚Äì heed the disclaimer; not an exercise in Ruby best practices Keep It Functional ‚Äì iPhone Test Automation talks about another automation framework for mobile. At some point Selenium is going to grow Objective-C bindings I fear.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #79
item.description: The only links left now are ones currently open in tabs right now. Hurray! November‚Äôs SFSE was Continuous Deployment At Mozilla: slides, video Practical Web Test Automation is a book available in both a free and paid editions. I haven‚Äôt looked at it so can‚Äôt comment how good or bad it is. The Why, What and How of Software Test Automation isn‚Äôt too horrible, though I don‚Äôt like the word ‚Äòguideline‚Äô and of course the measurement section at the bottom is complete hokum.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #78
item.description: Look! A light at the end of the tunnel! ASP.NET MVC + Selenium + IISExpress ‚Äì You don‚Äôt see too many Windows how-to‚Äôs. Not sure if they just don‚Äôt get tweeted about or is more a sign of that community. Write Logs for Machines, use JSON is a nice idea. I wonder if (when) the major CI containers will land on a pseudo-standard for consuming JSON Remote File Upload using Selenium 2‚Äôs FileDetectors shows yet another area I need to figure out in WebDriver (not Selenium 2 as Santi so stubbornly referred to it as üôÇ Janky is GitHub‚Äôs CI server.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #77
item.description: No. Really. A Smattering every day this week and I‚Äôll have the link queue cleared. Go! Mentioned in #74, Automating Web Performance data collection with BrowserMob Proxy and Selenium is more than just a link to GitHub Of course you are using the excellent Requests module rather than urllib2 which ships with Python; but are you using envoy instead of subprocess? Grabbing Screenshots of Failed Selenium Tests uses some JUnit magic.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #76
item.description: Post ten links, find seven more to add to the queue. Selenium Page Objects and Abstraction is one person‚Äôs attempt at writing down how they describe POs Running Geb specs using a separate driver profile to test mobile views in Grails shows how to create a custom Firefox profile in WebDriver Django and Selenium on Jenkins/Hudson (Headless) is yet another tutorial around xvfb but has a trick at the end I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve seen Python‚Äôs concurrent.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #75
item.description: And home. Which mean 100% more internets! Or at least 98% more. As things like native-driver become more prevalent, knowing how to do Continuous Integration for iOS projects with Jenkins CI will become more important Chocolatey seems like a nice and big step towards managing Windows build slaves SST (Selenium Simple Test) comes out of Ubuntu and has a quick introductory screencast. Automate Salesforce Config Changes with Selenium is a contest.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #74
item.description: It is kinda hard to do these without reliable internet‚Ä¶ dear hotels, fix. your. internet. Testing Facebook Login with Selenium has some nice Python helpers to dealing with Facebook auth VBS WebDriver ‚Äì ummm, wtf?! Python Browsermob Proxy Library ‚Äì the best code is code you don‚Äôt have to write yourself. (Thanks David!) I saw A Few of My Favorite (Python) Things at CodeMash last week and learned a few things def test = new BDDMadeEasy(Selenium,EasyB,Groovy) is a writeup from a recent presenter at the Greater Boston Selenium User Group Receive SMS alerts when a Selenium test fails seems like both a good idea and a bad one at the same time Have you always wanted to automate minesweeper?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #73
item.description: Two Ruby gems rwebspec-webdriver ‚Äì Executable functional specification for web applications in RSpec syntax and Selenium-WebDriver loadable_component ‚Äì Ruby implementation of LoadableComponent A three-parter on building a framework showing there is more than one way to skin the framework cat. Testing Concepts Base Classes Putting it all together Another three-parter on Is the Cost of Continuous Integration Worth the Value on Your Program? ‚Äì part 1, part 2, part 3

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #72
item.description: January means its time to escape from under the deadlines I found myself under during December so some of this stuff is a month old (or older!). Hopefully it is still interesting though. Localizing automation well is something I‚Äôve seen people struggle with. Creating Multi-Language Web Applications with Zend_Translate is a possible solution for PHP folks. Using Spinach with Selenium and of course Spinach seems to be a different implementation of Cucumber.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #71
item.description: Looking like there might also be one later in the week too‚Ä¶ As we start to transistion the web over the HTML5, I keep thinking about incorporating some ‚Äòstatic‚Äô checks into Se scripts. HTML5 Accessibility Chops: using nested figure elements explains some good (and bad) ways to use Jim took my nudging the organizing tests post I linked to last time and expanded on Organize Your Tests, Part II: Use Metadata!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #70
item.description: That‚Äôs it for this week. üôÇ For TestMate / Java folks, TextMate-Bundle-Selenium-Java could be interesting. We‚Äôve all made Oopses when writing / interpreting Se scripts, so it is important to remember that Mistakes: Transparency is Best Organizing scripts is one of those topics that gets both too much and not enough attention. Organizing Your Tests adds to the discussion ‚Äî though completely omits using ‚Äòtags‚Äô (which his product supports‚Ä¶) Not sure how this will affect automation of Android or not, but still pretty cool.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #69
item.description: In honor of this edition I provide‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶in which I also date myself. CITCon is another one of those conferences I should go to but haven‚Äôt. Yet! 7 continuous integration ideas from CITCon is a quick list from the most recent iteration. Testing Facebook authentication with Rails 3 Cucumber, Capybara, Selenium has a nice little trick to get Facebook to authenticate back to your Rails stack. pennyworth is a ‚Äòcontinuous packaging system‚Äô which seems like an interesting description.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #68
item.description: Its been almost a month, so time for a flurry of Smatterings. Maven has a bad reputation in some circles (ignoring for a second that you are using Java‚Ä¶), but should you be using it the QuickStart Archetype looks interesting. Why Your Monitoring Is Lying To You talks about types of logging which are valuable both from a Continuous Delivery perspective and for checking the health of your application during long script runs.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #67
item.description: Spinach is a Cucumber-esque BDD framework that was advertised on twitter as having ‚Äòless regex magic‚Äô. Not sure if it has grown Se support yet, but I have no doubt that it will soon. Coping With Big C.I. is full of stuff that is useful for even Small C.I. Sane AJAX Testing in Selenium uses ‚Äòreintroduced page loading‚Äô for what I would call a ‚Äòlatch‚Äô but describes it better I think.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #66
item.description: Aside from one of the dog‚Äôs tummy making noises that imply a big mess to clean up later, this scheduling thing seems to be working out. Heard someone talk about doing bitmap comparisons last week somewhere. Adaptive Images tricks I suspect are going to become more commonplace. Good luck with that. Se is best at interaction, structure and content checks; not does-it-look-the-way-some-human-intended. Robots where robots should be used. Humans where humans should be used.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #65
item.description: Trying something new; queuing up the catch-up post while I have time to catch-up. I‚Äôve been lead to believe that Functional Testing with Arquillian is a Big Deal&tm;. Of course, I just see a lot of Java‚Ä¶ If one thread raises an exception, why aren‚Äôt other threads‚Äô finally blocks called? is an interesting question with a nice answer. If you start running scripts in parallel, this, and the GIL is something to keep in mind.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #64
item.description: How did I fall behind again already?!?! This is a pretty good deck. Automation Isn‚Äôt All Shiny Toys If your work is divided in time-based goals then providing videos of the end result is a fantastic idea. See Dave‚Äôs Q3/2011 in review. The last two screencasts directly relate to Se The training wheels came off is outstanding! I‚Äôve been saying this around Se-IDE for years. If you have tried automation-in-anger with Python, then you have likely spent some time swearing at the GIL.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #63
item.description: Watir to WebDriver: Unit Test Frameworks ‚Äì Well, its ‚Äòbig‚Äô news. Of course, Watir can use WebDriver so they didn‚Äôt have to port their scripts to a different API (I sure hope they have the API well abstracted away from their scripts). And of course the title of the post implies that Facebook thinks that Watir/Selenium scripts are ‚ÄòUnit‚Äô tests which is suspect at best‚Ä¶ Selenium tests for Jenkins ‚Äî Yup; Jenkins now has a set of Se scripts for it.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #62
item.description: All opinions, all the time‚Ä¶ It all began with Test Design for Automation which lead to Automated Test Design (riffing/ripping off Alan Page) And then through some weird Jedi mind control there was Design for *GUI* Automation which in turn led to more UI test design (once more from Alan Page) And heck, why have two articles from the same author when you can have three?! It‚Äôs (probably) a Design Problem ‚Äî though I don‚Äôt think Chris has riffed off this one yet‚Ä¶ Remember, Not Every Test Should be Automated!

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #61
item.description: ‚ÄòThese are the people in your neighbourhood‚Ä¶‚Äô Like the power of WebDriver, but not the API? Watir WebDriver will get you going with the Watir API. Lots of useful stuff there. So does Alister Scott‚Äôs WatirMelon blog Sikuli Plays Angry Birds on Google Games ‚Äî just because scripts that play games are fun. cukeforker is for ‚ÄòForking cukes and VNC displays.‚Äô First time I‚Äôve seen a group of machines referred to as a ‚Äòfleet‚Äô, but its appropriate.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #60
item.description: This instalment of catch-up week is brought to you by the letters C and I. The pre-scm-buildstep plugin for jenkins adds a useful step into the job workflow. Understanding your tools is important. Here is an explanation of Jenkings Action and its subtypes You think your CI setup is impressive? Check out the Apache Foundation‚Äôs Jenkins server The easiest way to get CI going is with the ubiquitious but completely unoffically Ant JUnit XML format.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #59
item.description: Its been a month and a half since the last one of these, and the volume of links I have collected illustrates that. So this week is now a cleanup week. How Browsers Work: Behind the Scenes of Modern Web Browsers seems to be one of those articles that people who automate browsers for a living should be familiar with. 100% Test Coverage is always the goal. Continuous Deployment and Data Visualization reminds us that if some data is good, more is often better.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #58
item.description: And here we go again with more links than I thought I had collected‚Ä¶ There are a metric tonne of site on the internets which are on how to scam your way through a Se interview. Hiring Selenium QA people provides some fodder on how one could look for and hire Se folk. Why I don‚Äôt use spork reminds us that pain is [sometimes] a good thing. The Jenkins project is having a conference on October 2 in the same hotel that SeConf was held.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #57
item.description: Phew. The links made it through the Lion installation. Distributing the Same Test to Multiple Processes shows a technique for debugging flaky scripts Repeat after me: I will not automate GMail unless I am Google. Or if you will, you will do something like what is described in Verify email confirmation using Selenium. Notice that they are not using Se for it. Selenium and Nagios is something more teams should do I think.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #56
item.description: Safari is starting to whinge about how many tabs I have open which means it is time for another post. Ripple-UI is a cross-platform, mobile web application emulation environment. From RIM. Could be something interesting. Tips From Our Codebase To Help You Write Reliable Selenium Tests has nothing I don‚Äôt violently disagree with. And makes me think we should just add Implicit Waits to the Se Server and be done with it.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #55
item.description: Last week we released Se-IDE 1.1.0 which now features WebDriver formats and Se 2.1.0 was released about an hour ago. Simon will post something shortly-ish on what‚Äôs changed. I haven‚Äôt messed around with HTML5 goodies yes, but fake-html5 seems like it could be interesting. The Yii framework has grown WebDriver support. Now if only there were not two competing PHP implementations for them to have to choose from‚Ä¶ If you are using Python‚Äôs native packaging system to share your framework, then Lies, More Lies and Python Packaging Documentation on `package_data` could spare you some headache

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #54
item.description: Two Smatterings in two days?!!? That never happens. Well, except when I get behind and have a metric tonne of links queued up. Next week appears to be Meetup week with ones in London on Tuesday, Toronto on Wednesday and San Francisco on Thursday. It‚Äôs like we coordinated or something. (But didn‚Äôt.) Last month‚Äôs SFSE meetup was on framework design. Here is the slides and the video. Selenium Smells goes on a bit of a rant (and provides solutions) to people putting sleeps in their code instead of proper synchronization.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #53
item.description: Well, since the last Smattering there hasn‚Äôt been much in the community. Oh. Well, except for hitting the 2.0.0 milestone. Which seems like a good time to remind people that: Selenium is the project name Selenium 1 is a project version Selenium 2 is a project version Selenium Remote Control (RC) is an API name Selenium WebDriver is an API name A person upgrades from Selenium 1 to Selenium 2 A person migrates from RC to WebDriver And with that soap boxing, here are some links for your consumption.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #52
item.description: Welcome to the Canada Day edition of the less-than-weekly-now collection of Selenium / Automation links that is the Smattering of Selenium. Selenium Advanced User Interactions illustrates how this new API (which is part of WebDriver) can use used to do things like drag-and-drop on Canvas elements. Things you (probably) didn‚Äôt know about xargs is one of those things to keep tucked away in your toolbox. Especially if you find yourself having to shell out in your scripts.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #51
item.description: Two big releases last week… Selenium IDE 1.0.11 was released ‚Äî with Firefox 4 support. Finally. And just in time for people to start agitating for Firefox 5 support. official announcement, unofficial announcement Selenium 2 RC1 (and RC2) were released which marks the first official release of the new in-server grid behaviour. Even if you are not using the WebDriver API or grid functionality, you should be updating your environment to this.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #50
item.description: Half a century! And because I am late doing this, the Selenium Test Day for Addons.Mozilla.org ‚Äî which is today! gets top billing. Its actually going on Right Now. Looking to practice script writing and/or up your profile? This is a great way. And now for the usual stuff. .NET Headless browser options looks at various options that might be available to you if you want something like HTMLUnit but for .

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #49
item.description: Here is the next 10 links as I play catch-up. First up is the Selenium Conf videos. There are only seven up currently, but as they are processed they will be posted Silicon Valley Continuous Integration Summit, April 7, 2011 Virtual Hudson Build Environments ‚Äì Part One, Part Two The second last paragraph of So you think you know automation? Part One is extremely important if you re doing automation. Which you likely are if you are reading this.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #48
item.description: It‚Äôs catch-up time again! Here is the first 10. Automated tests for HTML5 offline web applications with Capybara and Selenium shows how a custom Firefox profile lets you automate Offline capabilities of HTML5 apps Robot Framework‚Äôs SeleniumLibrary 2.7 has been released primarily to pick up 2.0b3 of the Selenium Server. There was a series of posts about using Selenium with Drupal recently. Selenium testing in Drupal Run Selenium tests in Drupal on Debian headless Drupal Selenium tests API Using XPath Axes for locating elements in Selenium discusses some of the more advanced ways of finding elements via XPath I‚Äôll follow that up with a link to the cssify project which will attempt to automatically convert XPath locators to CSS And since we‚Äôre now onto CSS‚Ä¶ CSS Stress Testing and Performance Profiling discusses the stress-css bookmarklet.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #47
item.description: Nothing says ‚ÄòHello Monday!‚Äô like a batch of links and a wife with a kidney stone. Eradicating Non-Determinism in Tests is a nice essay by Martin Fowler and applies to Se as Left uncontrolled, non-deterministic tests can completely destroy the value of an automated regression suite. Reminds us to disable automated updates on your remote machines. Selenium Simple Automation Infrastructure is a framework built on top of Selenium using Python to make writing scalable, data driven, functional web tests easier with code.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #46
item.description: Let‚Äôs put Selenium IDE on Firefox 4 is Available for Testing! Now! outside of the normal list. We have a ‚Äòworking‚Äô version of Se-IDE for FF4, but don‚Äôt really have too too much faith in it (or at least I don‚Äôt). Please help test it. Eight Techniques to Improve Your Tests is focused on unit tests, but I‚Äôm sure something can be gained from them Runners are great fun. How the play framework test runner works is therefor also great fun.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #45
item.description: A Smattering of Selenium #45 So of course by now everyone has seen Selenium 2.0b3: The Next Gen Browser Release and upgraded their rigs. Expect Selenium IDE at some point in the next week with support for FF4 ‚Äî if you just. can‚Äôt. wait. then you could try the bleeding edge for yourself. Logging any bugs you find; of course. Oh, and there is the whole Selenium Conference next week.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #44
item.description: What started out as the week of Capybara rounded itself out fairly nicely I‚Äôm not a fan of using 3rd party abstraction layers (1st party are full win though) but Capybara has a large marketshare so Capybara (and Selenium) with RSpec & Rails 3: quick tutorial is likely going to be of interest to people. And while on the subject of Capybara, here is a post on Checking Invisible Elements in it.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #43
item.description: The big thing in the new last week was ColdFusion. Yes, ColdFusion. I was amazed how much mention it got on Twitter. Introducing CFSelenium ‚Äì A Native ColdFusion Client Library for Selenium-RC Export Selenium-IDE Scripts in CFSelenium (ColdFusion) Format GitHub repo CFSelenium and VirtualBox SeleniumCamp happened over the weekend and from the looks of things was a success. And had almost an even number of women as men ‚Äî which is almost unheard of at these sorts of things.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #42
item.description: Is this week‚Äôs post the Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything Selenium? Selenium 2 ‚Äì Get Number of Rows in a Table illustrates what is advertised, though it feels like there has to be a shorter way to do this along the lines of getXpathCount() or getCssCount() Atlassian Plugin SDK ‚Äì how to provide optional selenium tests explains how to wire up Se with the Atlassian toolkit and has a couple task specific tips as well.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #41
item.description: There isn‚Äôt an official announcement anywhere (yet) but Selenium 2.0b2 was released a couple hours ago. Time to upgrade all your servers. Beta 3 is going to focus on IE9 and FF4 support. Meanwhile‚Ä¶ A Webinar on Automated Selenium Testing with Maestro 3 could be interesting if you are considering the Maestro platform. And sticking with the webinar idea, Sauce Labs is hosting Selenium 2 Webinar: The Next Generation of Web and Mobile Application Testing After a bit of stagnation, the official Python drivers are starting to get updated again.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #40
item.description: You would think by now that I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised by the number of links I collect in a week. The big news last week is that we (Selenium) have successfully avoided the whole Hudson/Jenkins drama by joining the Software Freedom Conservancy. Se Announcement Conservancy Announcement Speaking of Hudson/Jenkins, here is how to upgrade a Hudson install to Jenkinss I don‚Äôt like a lot of the messaging of the whole ‚ÄòLean Startup‚Äô scene, but they have some things to steal though.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #39
item.description: Hey look! All caught up ‚Äî only took a month‚Ä¶ My opinions on Continuous Deployment are pretty widely known, but the IMVU folks certainly have a lot of neat tricks to ‚Äòborrow‚Äô. Such as Buildbot and Intermittent Tests Dealing with an API that returns XML? Your scripts don‚Äôt care about the readibility, but it helps you as the human if it is formatted pretty. xml formatter is a glorious time save in that case.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #38B
item.description: Will today be the day I finish three weeks of catch-up? Well, no.. UI Tests ‚Äì putting it all together summarizes the series of posts using Watir and Cucumber, but the ideas could be converted to Se pretty easily. I haven‚Äôt read it, but Essential Software Testdesign is now available for free [legitimately] as a pdf. Test Design is something I expect to see more discussion around in 2011 when it comes to Se automation.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #38A
item.description: No. Really. I‚Äôm almost caught up. Want input in a non-english language but don‚Äôt want to convert your whole machine? InputKing might be able to help. And the fact it is in a browser means we can use it via Se. HAR (HTTP Archive) is the format the cool kids are talking about, and now there is a har gem so you can make use of HAR files in you [Ruby] scripts.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #37B
item.description: Let‚Äôs see how many announcements there were that didn‚Äôt get pushed out in a timely manner today shall we? Well, there is of course Selenium Conf is coming and you have until Friday to get your proposals in. Last I heard we had 37 which is impressive, but I think 50 should be doable. On the meetup side of things there is Boston on January 25 NYC on January 26 (its not on the site yet, but I‚Äôm speaking, so trust me, it exists) London on March 23 SeleniumCamp (English) is coming to Kiev at the end of February.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #37A
item.description: My scheme for catching up with links last week ran afoul of 900 geeks and their families melting the internets at CodeMash 2.0.1.1. So let‚Äôs try it again this week. Capturing screenshots on script failure is a common trick and Capturing Web Page Screenshots with Selenium 2 is the first post I have seen that explains how to do with with Selenium WebDriver XPath marks the spot uses a treasure map analogy around how to create good XPath ‚Äî but at the same time propagates the ‚ÄòXPath is Inherently Evil‚Äô myth.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #36B
item.description: Second in a week-long series of catch-up posts. But before I get to the next batch of links, don‚Äôt forget to submit your proposals to speak at the first Selenium Conference. I‚Äôm pretty sure we‚Äôre going to be trying to pick out the talks next week. Can we please adopt this as the official poster for Selenium? Please? If you are a C# developer looking to get started with Selenium WebDriver, Automated Testing with Selenium 2 and NUnit seems like a good place to start Per the who ‚Äòbringing order to the universe‚Äô, Watir-WebDriver: A detailed introduction shows how to drive Watir using Selenium WebDriver UI Automation: Tricks and Traps has, well, umm, tricks to try and traps to avoid.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #36A
item.description: I have drastically fallen behind on the link reporting, but not the collecting, so this week‚Äôs Smattering will be multi-part. The ‚Äòbig‚Äô news falls for this edition is two fold ‚Äì We‚Äôre having a conference! Selenium Conference 2011 is April 4 ‚Äì 6, 2011 in San Francisco. See the site for more information. (And I think our friends at Watir are going to be in the same space the day before.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #35
item.description: (If I wasn‚Äôt still recovering from a cold there would be something witty here.) We‚Äôll start this week with a cartoon So I know I have linked to playing pacman with se 2, but here is a site that explains the ghost behavior. If Google implemented the algorithms properly-ish, then this should be the ticket to crazy high scores. There should be a contest for this‚Ä¶ Cucumber + Cuke4Duke + Selenium (WebDriver) = Enlightenment is step-by-step instructions for using maven to wire all these things together.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #34
item.description: We‚Äôll start this week with the official announcement of ‚ÄòSelenium 1.0 Testing Tools: Beginner‚Äôs Guide‚Äô being available. Congrats David! (Still waiting for my copy‚Ä¶) There is now a DZone ‚Äòrefcard‚Äô for Selenium 2. Of course, the reason Se2 is alpha is the API isn‚Äôt done with at least one major addition still left so it will be out of date in a month, but still‚Ä¶ Here is another example of how to do Page Objects in Python Client-Side Profiling with Selenium 2 is David‚Äôs post about his recent London Selenium User Group talk Someone took the time to make a Selenium lens on Squidoo; which is going to get kinda circular once this post shows up on it.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #33
item.description: ‚Ä¶and here‚Äôs the links! Henrik Skupin was one of the speakers at the London Selenium Meetup and has written about the night and his talk Speaking of which, videos of the talks are now up Part of good automation is knowing how to code. So here are some sites that crossed my path this week for that Rails for Zombies Dive into HTML 5 HTML5 Rocks Cheezy continues his UI series which takes a detour over to WATIR land, but things are transferable.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #32
item.description: For those people paying attention to the goings-on in the Selenium world, yes, I am skipping something major until some of the details are worked out and announced. Until then, here are the links I accrued over the week. Selenium uses Bamboo for its CI infrastructure. This week saw an upgrade to the latest version so if you want bleeding-edge code, get it here The only browser Se has no real traction on right now is the BlackBerry one.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #31
item.description: The big news for last week was that I released Se-IDE 1.0.8 to very little fanfare. 1.0.9 should be a week or two and much more important a release. Cheesecake! is isn‚Äôt nearly as impractical as Pacman, but still adds to the Se2 example bucket. The London Se Meetup stuff from last week are starting to appear‚Ä¶ Client-side profiling with Se2 a summary How Mozilla uses Se Crowd-sourced Automated Firefox UI Testing Some notes from CITCON last week as well.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #30
item.description: I‚Äôve missed a couple weeks due to travel and a complete system lock which meant I lost all the links I had open but not saved. So these are the ones I have recovered. I have written a series of posts on how to do parallel execution of tests in JUnit 4 up on the Sauce Labs blog. Part One, Part 2 and Part Three Quick start with FitNesse and Selenium is a beginners guide to wiring Selenium and FitNesse together.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #29
item.description: A fair number of links this week. The vast majority of which were buried in annoying airport internet advertising frames‚Ä¶ This looks like it is Spanish which would normally mean it doesn‚Äôt get included but it Integra√ß√£o Selenium e Testlink explains how to integrate Se with TestLink. We, as a community, need to document this sort of thing more. JUnit 4 Vs TestNG is a somewhat biased comparison between JUnit 4 and TestNG; but useful none the less.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #28
item.description: So we go from not-enough-stuff-to-do-one to wow-this-will-take-awhile. And we‚Äôre off.. Tellurium is one of the many frameworks that absorb Se and has an article on InfoQ called Introducing the Tellurium Automated Testing Framework which, well, introduces the framework. In the first of many Cucumber related posts this week is Sean Grove‚Äôs Cucumber Sauce for doing parallel Cucumber runs on the Sauce infrastructure. Might be general enough to use outside of it as well.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #27
item.description: Seems I skipped a week, but that‚Äôs okay since there hasn‚Äôt been much in terms of volume (or maybe my clever search filter is a bit overly clever‚Ä¶). The big news I think is that there is now a Se driver for Node.js called Soda. I‚Äôm not sure I like the syntax, but I also don‚Äôt claim to know Node so it could be idiomatically correct which is more important than my blessing.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #26
item.description: It‚Äôs Labour Day here, so this post was written to backdrop of Sponge Bob. In case you were wondering. selenium-java-evidence appears to be another logging framework, this time with an emphasis on auditability. Personally, the reports from a CI server should be all that are required, but to each their own‚Ä¶ taza is an opinionated browser-based test framework webdry is a Python (jquery-inspired) wrapper for DRY:er access to the Selenium WebDriver Self-testing AppEngine apps with Saucelabs seems like a cool little (if very low level) trick to using Se inside AppEngine Sauce Labs released their Getting Started With Selenium guide and is looking for feedback on it Need to interact with a web service during a BrowserMob run?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #25
item.description: A day late, but that sort of thing happens when you have family. I keep telling myself I will document how to incorporate Se launching and result recording in QC, but never seem to find the excuse. Looks like Aaron found the excuse: Finding the API for a DLL, Connecting to HP/Mercury Quality Center from a client side script Also from Aaron is a cool Credit Card Generator which has nice id tags which makes for easy Se parsing.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #24
item.description: A bit late, but I‚Äôm in California for a Selenium Developers Meetup and my body doesn‚Äôt quite know where it is temporally. Don‚Äôt forget that tomorrow is the next meeting of the San Francisco Selenium folks which seems to be running a crowd sourced ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs stump Jason with our problems‚Äù session. Most of the ‚Äòmain‚Äô Se folk will be there. Test design theory is something that I have yet to really see covered much, so here are three articles on the similar idea of what to test and what to skip.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #23
item.description: I was at Agile 2010 in Orlando last week so missed doing the Smattering, so here is two weeks worth of links. There is crazy amounts of power hiding in that there JUnit 4 library ‚Äì such as @Rule. One usage of them is described here. A useful pattern indeed when doing something like BDD or ATDD The next SFSE has been announced; August 24 at LinkedIn. Se creator Jason Huggins will be fielding questions in a Q&A session on steroids.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #22
item.description: Happy Simcoe Day. Only a handful of links this week to mention. Kevin relaunched Mogotest ‚Äì see your website the way your users do. In a much earlier Smattering I think I linked to an announcement about a Se talk at Boston.rb. Well, here are the slides While not directly related to Se, the W3C has released their Unified Validator called, wait for it, Unicorn. So who is going to create the integration that magically sends pages to be validated there?

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #21
item.description: I thought it had been a slow week ‚Äî until I looked at how many browser windows I had open. I wonder if that was why things were feeling a bit sluggish‚Ä¶ Some bits of history from Simon Stewart First announcement of Selenium (outside of Thoughtworks) First announcement of WebDriver (again, outside of Thoughtworks) The ‚Äòmerger‚Äô announcement (aka Selenium 2) More history lessons on Cloud Computing Show #35 where Jason recounts the origin of Se (and other stuff)

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #20
item.description: 12 hours late, but I was driving draft horses all day so that‚Äôs my excuse and I‚Äôm sticking with it. Enjoy. I‚Äôm going for a nap. The big news this week was the next alpha of Se 2 came out. Time to update those automation machines. Like TestNG‚Äôs @BeforeClass and @AfterClass but using JUnit4? Using JUnit Nested Suites with Selenium RC to simulate TestNG suite and grouping annotations is a long titled post, but describes how to fake one out to act like the other.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #19
item.description: I‚Äôve got a full day of driving ahead of me to go to a client so this is the early-morning (for me) edition of the Smattering post. That of course means there will be an absolute link explosion in about 20 minutes. Dave talks about some of the stuff he is doing with Se-IDE in the post Improving Selenium IDE Another post on how to deal with file downloads in Se.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #18
item.description: Not too much this week with various holidays around the world, but still managed to dig some things up. Sauce Labs has started a webinar series and recently had one on using Cucumber and OnDemand. Cucumber and Robot Framework like tools are the coming wave of testing tools. Another bit of Sauce-ish news is the folks at Rally put up a post on how to get Se 2 scripts in their OnDemand cloud If writing Se scripts is ‚Äòprogramming‚Äô, then writing the controlling frameworks is real programming.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #17
item.description: Here are the posts dealing with Se, and/or automation in general that caught my eye and interest. Selenium Unit Test Reuse illustrates one way of iterating through environments and browsers in a script without using Se-Grid. I‚Äôve done similar tricks to this to some success ‚Äî the problem is usually reporting though, but you are all clever folks so I‚Äôm sure you could add it in. Adding a custom header is sometimes required when writing a script, but its not really that documented so Kevin wrote How to Perform Basic Authentication in Selenium which combines how to do basic auth and header injection.

item.title: A Smattering of Selenium #16
item.description: I‚Äôm going to start posting the Smattering posts here on the main Selenium blog, hopefully each Monday. For past ones see my personal blog‚Äôs archive Style Tests using Selenium and Robotframework ‚Äì With those simple steps we are able to do regression testing on our user interfaces that have strict standards Export Selenium IDE scripts for Grails ‚Äì A plugin which does exactly what the announcement says. Selenium XML Formatter ‚Äì Hurray for plugins!
